Hi. I think it's because when paintball hits an object it doesn't pop at the point where they meet. Instead, it pops somewhere on the back of the paintball. So when paint escapes outer layer of paintball it continues moving forward due to its inertia, but the spot where they met is occupied with paintball shell, the covering not the paint. So paint splashes around the shell that is pressed to an object and after that covering itself just fall to the ground.
How about both?

I killed my first camera filming a demonstration.  It was looking down into a container of acetone that I was using for chromatography.  One leg of the tripod gave out and the camera took a nosedive into the acetone.  Dissolved several plastic parts so that they stuck together.  I was able to get it to work without the plastic casing, but a capacitor inside kept shocking me, so I used it as an excuse to upgrade.
